770.25.text: And for starters I will submit

773.87.text: that politics need not be a dirty word.

779.17.text: Aristotle chose the word politics to name his tritest

783.50.text: on political philosophy because it concerned the matters

787.44.text: of the pollists, a form of political community

791.24.text: in ancient Greece we know as the city state.

795.79.text: to Aristotle was the most evolved form of community.

805.32.text: and organize themselves around shared principles, to create

810.22.text: and participate in a public life.

813.59.text: To serve the pollists was a high honor, a privilege.

819.08.text: Now today, the word politics is rarely employed

907.73.text: that would have been a higher number but 70%.

911.33.text: Only 32% agreed that running for office is an honorable thing

919.61.text: As the Harvard study illustrates too many people,

1947.94.text: And my answer is couched in that sense.

1952.18.text: I liked it as far as it went.

1955.90.text: I like the idea of shining the spotlight on higher education.

1960.00.text: I like the idea of shining the spotlight

1962.62.text: on public institutions of higher education.

1966.36.text: And so because if our country is going to thrive with countries

1973.69.text: like China out there, putting lots of money

1977.94.text: into education we're going to need to do some of that as well.

1982.96.text: What I would like to see added, so I'm viewing that as part one

1992.20.text: Where are those students going to go to finish their Bachelors

1994.73.text: and get a post graduate degree, the four year universities?

1999.09.text: And in particular the four year public research universities

2004.45.text: like a Michigan, like California that experience

2011.38.text: of public disinvestment over the years.

2014.70.text: I think making the public case for community colleges is going

2018.73.text: to help raise the public perception

2027.42.text: But I don't want to create in young people an expectation

2031.50.text: that then they won't be able to go to a four year school

2033.65.text: if we don't also do something for them as well.

2036.99.text: I hope that is part deux of the proposal.

2044.62.text: >> Hi, my name's Diana Wine [assumed spelling]

2045.99.text: and I'm a second year Master of Public Policy student

2048.87.text: with an interest in international affairs.

2051.24.text: As a woman who's also interested in public service,

2053.86.text: thank you so much for being here.

2055.78.text: So the next question is about domestic politics.

2059.79.text: What factors do you think explain the rise of partisanship

2063.03.text: and extremism in U.S. politics of the last few decades?

2066.97.text: What can we do to change this?

2070.53.text: >> I think our country has seen a couple things and realized

2075.43.text: that we have had, historically had some periods

2081.81.text: And the question is how we work our way out of them.

2085.01.text: But I think the current one is mobilized by a few things.

2090.59.text: One is the way we do congressional districting.

2097.81.text: Means we have far too many congressional districts

2101.56.text: They're not competitive in the general election.

2105.12.text: And because our voting patterns tend to be low turnout

2109.50.text: in primary, that tends to drive you to campaign

2113.97.text: to the party base as opposed to knowing that you have to reach

2119.08.text: out to either independent voters or even voters

2123.71.text: of the other party in order to win.

2131.39.text: And that problem has gotten pretty bad.

2133.46.text: I think someone did a study that showed, I think there were

2138.29.text: of the house seats are truly competitive

2143.68.text: Now those who run statewide, governors and senators,

2147.25.text: there's a slightly different dynamic there.

2153.39.text: But again particularly in the senate you see some of the same,

2159.50.text: same, same, because of the importance of the party primary.

2168.15.text: I'm sorry, I respect the Supreme Court.

2171.08.text: I'm a lawyer, I've argued before the court.

2173.51.text: I'm a member of the Supreme Court Bar.

2176.03.text: I think they have really screwed up the first amendment

2180.27.text: where public campaign financing is concerned.

2187.56.text: And they got it wrong because no one

2190.03.text: on the court I think fundamentally appreciates how

2197.23.text: And I also find it hard to equate corporate expenditures

2204.45.text: as protected first amendment speech in this arena.

2208.33.text: One thing about me that you might find interesting or not

2211.99.text: but I'm going to say it anyway.

2214.14.text: But when I ran for governor I was publically financed

2221.28.text: because between the time I ran for AG where I had

2224.40.text: to make cold calls for money and do all that and the time I ran

2229.35.text: for governor, Arizona enacted a clean elections law.

2232.76.text: And the way it worked was if you got so many $5 contributions

2239.48.text: and it had to be geographically distributed throughout the state

2243.77.text: then you qualified for clean election financing.

2247.21.text: And you got X amount for the primary

2249.41.text: and then X amount for the general.

2252.90.text: If your opponents ran the traditional way

2256.22.text: and were raising their own money and they broke a cap,

2260.87.text: they broke a certain number then you got matched dollar

2264.97.text: for dollar in what they were raising.

2267.64.text: And the match of course obviously is a key factor.

2272.43.text: It was a, so when I ran for governor the first time,

2276.63.text: I ran again a really nice guy.

2278.60.text: In the end we actually liked each other because we'd been

2282.23.text: in so many debates and things and found

2284.34.text: out we actually liked each other.

2287.15.text: But his first thing when he came

2289.81.text: out of the primary he had a big dinner with President Bush

2295.59.text: as the speaker at, you know, $500 tickets

2303.29.text: But he was at the cap because he was running the old fashion way.

2306.75.text: So I called him up and I said Matt,

2308.75.text: can I sell tickets to your dinner?

2311.91.text: Because I would get every ticket,

2314.23.text: so I was getting [inaudible] and I didn't have to pay

2315.95.text: for the dinner, right, so it was total money for me.

2318.72.text: Which he still is bitter about that part.

2323.15.text: I may be the only democrat that President Bush raised money for.

2328.96.text: That whole system has been thrown out obviously

2331.35.text: because of the Supreme Court's prudence in campaign finance.

2334.83.text: And I think that's led to partisanship.

2337.75.text: And I think the third thing may be just, you know,

2342.92.text: the issues our nation, we're, you know, we are,

2346.57.text: our nation needs to be addressing economic inequality.

2350.64.text: And things like and energy policy that makes sense.

2355.87.text: And how do we deal with the rise Jihadist extremism.

2361.24.text: I mean, there are lots of big complicated problems.

2366.33.text: And they're hard to explain and deal

2371.72.text: And our candidates have been able to resort to platitudes

2376.89.text: as opposed to having a conversation with voters

2381.06.text: that makes sense that has an appreciation of the issues.

2385.58.text: And then they're stuck with those platitudes

2388.03.text: when they get elected because that's what they said they

2391.40.text: And so the ability to compromise once they have new

2394.80.text: or additional information or additional appreciation

2398.37.text: of the complexity of an issue, that has gone away.

2402.02.text: So those are three things I would identify.

2407.48.text: So universities are under enormous pressure both public

2410.16.text: and private to reduce costs and even are challenged to compete

2414.12.text: with online education in terms of cost.

2416.94.text: Part of that could you then tell us what do you see as the value

2419.90.text: of physical brick and mortar university?

2422.33.text: >> You know, I think that's right.

2427.28.text: in a lot of different ways.

2428.47.text: And everybody wants to bring down the costs

2435.88.text: And large institutions will always have some costs

2440.11.text: that are unnecessary, places where there's waste,

2443.62.text: places where things could be streamlined.

2445.32.text: And we owe it to the institutions we run,

2448.77.text: and I'm sure President Schlissel's doing the same

2450.87.text: thing, is to help root those things out.

2454.76.text: And make administrative changes that save money.

2458.56.text: However, however, let's not excuse the lack

2463.25.text: of public investment in higher education on the fact

2467.92.text: that you need classrooms and faculty and laboratories

2471.97.text: and studios and other things to give students what I think is

2478.12.text: in involved in this model of higher education.

2481.60.text: You know, of the public research university where you are working

2485.30.text: with a faculty that is not only transmitting knowledge

2490.81.text: You cannot cut your way to excellence

2493.28.text: in that kind of an atmosphere.

2497.73.text: So I'm going to DC tomorrow and I keep, I keep making up more.

2501.59.text: But I want to make, I can pause on online education.

2507.23.text: and the theory was mooks will solve everything.

2510.96.text: And it turns out, no, not so much.

2517.51.text: and online hybrid type courses make sense as tools in toolbox

2525.46.text: on how we actually educate in the.

2527.49.text: I mean, we would be, we have new technology now.

2530.21.text: Why shouldn't we figure out how best to use it?

2533.93.text: But it needs to be integrated within the overall context

2537.53.text: of what we believe comprises an education at a university.

2548.44.text: So following on this theme of education,

2551.02.text: one of our audience members just told us, just 9% of those

2554.55.text: who grow up in poor families get a college degree while 54%

2560.59.text: What can universities do to reduce this enormous gap?

2563.88.text: >> Yeah, you know, and when you look at, you know, the creation

2568.37.text: of the public university, the moral act,

2571.35.text: the land grant university, part of it was designed to make sure

2575.50.text: that as the United States expanded westward students would

2579.34.text: have access to universities without having to go

2582.23.text: to a private school in Massachusetts.

2585.84.text: And, you know, that model has worked well.

2589.73.text: But the fact of the matter is

2593.28.text: that those numbers I believe are accurate numbers.

2597.81.text: We need to work obviously in the K12 world so that students

2603.15.text: who go to schools that are in poor areas are not, you know,

2607.81.text: just by virtue of that prohibited

2611.86.text: from going a Michigan or a Cal, UCLA.

2618.87.text: The second thing we need to do is create pipeline

2622.42.text: and pipeline programs in the high schools

2627.06.text: And the third thing we need

2628.24.text: to do is make sure our financial aid programs are robust.

2631.71.text: So at the University of California,

2634.01.text: I don't know how it works here.

2635.39.text: At the University of California if you are a California resident

2641.06.text: and that includes undocumented students and if you come

2646.58.text: from a family that makes than $80,000 a year, tuition is free

2653.36.text: And then there's a middle class scholarship that's coming

2658.88.text: Fifty five percent of the students at the University

2661.46.text: of California do not pay tuition.

2663.46.text: That's an engine of social mobility.

2666.91.text: We want to keep that up but we can't provide them the quality

2672.62.text: of education their predecessors got and do

2676.36.text: that without some more money getting into the system.

2680.10.text: And the more money either has to come from the state or it needs

2685.11.text: to come from tuition from those who are paying tuition.

2688.62.text: And we now need to keep in front of us the middle class.

2694.11.text: Because in California the cost of living

2698.29.text: where our campuses are, the cost of living are high and/or

2702.92.text: if you come from a family where maybe it's over 80

2712.22.text: about that right now as we move forward.

2718.53.text: As we talk about getting students into higher education,

2724.08.text: an audience member was wondering what are the limits

2726.69.text: of free speech on college campuses especially regarding

2733.47.text: >> Well I think college campuses are really

2741.68.text: in way they are the epitome of public areas

2746.60.text: for free speech even of the most controversial

2753.81.text: And we have to recognize that and appreciate that.

2763.67.text: So how speech is conducted and where speech turns

2768.13.text: into something that renders the community unsafe

2775.07.text: as a violent activity going on, that's a different issue.

2779.21.text: But by and large these campuses are for the exchange

2783.75.text: of ideas regardless of how ill founded and objectionable.

2788.53.text: And students and faculty, staff, have to understand

2794.82.text: and appreciate that free speech aspect

2797.55.text: of the university as part of the deal.

2799.85.text: It's part of the deal of going to a university.

2803.52.text: We respect those free speech rights.

2812.61.text: >> So as former Secretary for Homeland Security,

2816.08.text: a lot of audience members are wondering especially given the

2819.29.text: recent events in Paris, how does the U.S. best address thoughts

2824.58.text: of terrorism and also how do we prevent atrocities like the ones

2828.18.text: that have taken place in France?

2830.14.text: >> Yeah, well first of all I think, you know, there was,

2837.45.text: the headline after the attack of 911 there was a headline

2840.82.text: in one French newspaper, you know, we are all Americans now.

2845.33.text: And I think the reverse is true given the events of last week.

2852.24.text: France has a related but different a little bit issue

2859.36.text: in a way from a security standpoint

2861.29.text: than the United States where Jihadist activity is concerned.

2866.63.text: They have probably numerically a lot more Jihadists.

2875.31.text: And there are whole elements of the suburbs around Paris

2880.82.text: that have been discussed as hot beds

2887.34.text: And so I'm sure there'll be a lot of, you know, going back

2893.29.text: and looking at what happened that enabled the attacks

2898.37.text: And why there wasn't greater eyesight on these individuals.

2903.08.text: But it's awfully difficult to keep eyesight on everybody

2908.26.text: that has, you know, gone to Syria or Iraq

2916.36.text: In the United States we have some knowledge of those

2922.71.text: who have gone into that area of the world and returned.

2926.42.text: Gone to join the fight and returned.

2931.13.text: And we also are working very closely

2934.47.text: with the Muslim community which in a way itself is harmed

2940.96.text: by this activity because of the kind

2945.44.text: of the spillover into all Muslims.

2950.17.text: Whereas we know this is a very, very small extremist group

2956.55.text: We need to do more by way of outreaching, communication

2966.19.text: If you've really done good engagement and you know people

2970.26.text: and they know you and you've gone

2972.54.text: to each other's celebrations and you've gone

2974.86.text: to each other's sorrows and you've exchanged things.

2978.25.text: And the community there's trust that develops and trust

2983.64.text: in a crisis situation is unbelievably helpful.

2987.98.text: So going to Ferguson, what did we see after Ferguson?

2994.52.text: Clearly issues had been festering for a long time.

2998.68.text: And but that kind of community policing which goes on in a lot

3002.78.text: of communities in the United States had not been undertaken

3008.33.text: And the result was the division and the violence

3011.90.text: that we saw there that has spread into other,

3017.38.text: some other communities across the United States.

3021.87.text: or not nearly some you might have expected.

3024.24.text: Why? Because there had been a lot of, a lot of investment made

3030.20.text: in that community engagement and outreach.

3033.00.text: It's not a platitude to do it.

3034.54.text: It takes time to do it.

3036.00.text: It takes resource of time to do it but it can be done.

3042.85.text: Given your professional experience both in California

3045.10.text: and Arizona and as secretary in the federal government,

3050.74.text: it's been in the news a lot lately particularly

3054.83.text: Audience members are wondering do you think President Obama

3057.22.text: should have pursued a comprehensive immigration reform

3060.91.text: instead of healthcare in his first term.

3063.06.text: And also did his recent actions

3065.93.text: of executive action go far enough

3067.40.text: or what are your thoughts on that as well?

3069.37.text: >> Yeah, I want to be careful now.

3071.92.text: I'm speaking as Janet Napolitano not as, I'm not representing

3077.07.text: in a official opinion of the Board of Regents

3082.67.text: But as an individual, no I think the second guessing on,

3087.77.text: you know, going after healthcare is untord [phonetic].

3090.52.text: You know, healthcare and the ability

3093.29.text: to get healthcare is important to everybody,

3098.95.text: etc. And it just turned out, it occupied all the space.

3103.72.text: And that's, that's just the way it was.

3110.92.text: the executive the recent executive orders,

3113.10.text: I know the President was patient and, you know,

3119.14.text: waited 550 some odd days from when he got a senate bill

3123.78.text: that was pretty much a bill he was not only supportive

3128.77.text: It was the product of a lot of work.

3130.94.text: I know I was involved in it.

3132.40.text: A lot of compromise, I know I was involved in some of that.

3138.56.text: And the house refused to even hear it.

3143.15.text: And at that point, you know, it was very clear

3146.10.text: that they were sending signals at the election.

3147.96.text: It was going to be the same situation, same old, same old.

3151.21.text: And the President said enough, no more.

3153.82.text: I'm going to use the authority I have under law

3158.37.text: to make some decisions about immigration enforcement.

3162.69.text: And he issued the executive orders.

3165.52.text: That, the way he did it, having worked and drafted DACA,

3169.78.text: which is deferred action for childhood arrivals.

3172.33.text: So I'm very familiar with the law in this arena.

3174.43.text: I think he went about as far as he should go.

3180.51.text: Oh yeah, you could always say, you know what, I'm just going

3182.40.text: to rewrite the whole immigration code and forget congress.

3185.49.text: But the question is not only could be should

3188.35.text: because recognize the next executive could say well

3192.04.text: if President Obama did this so I'm going to do that.

3195.06.text: So he's also aware of, we all should be aware of kind

3198.45.text: of the presidential nature of this.

3201.59.text: I think he went about as far as he should go in this arena.

3206.06.text: And now the question is implementation.

3207.77.text: And now the question is will we have a congress

3210.88.text: that actually takes up a difficult complicated issue

3214.88.text: with the notion that they want

3217.05.text: to help solve it not just pick a fight.

3223.09.text: I have no strong feelings in this [inaudible].

3228.01.text: >> As Secretary of Homeland Security, did you know

3234.01.text: And did you think that the program was actually effective

3240.73.text: >> You know, I, you know, without going into what,

3246.51.text: what intel I receive or didn't receive as a secretary,

3254.15.text: I think that the president was serious

3258.35.text: about really looking at privacy issues.

3261.38.text: And setting up a process by which those are reviewed

3268.06.text: I think that's a very increasingly, you know,

3272.90.text: Technology changes and it changes so rapidly

3276.91.text: and the capacity of intelligence gathering agencies changes.

3282.24.text: There needs to be a way for the president

3285.41.text: to have greater visibility into the, that gathering process

3291.53.text: and how the intel is being used.

3294.00.text: So I don't know where that, that is standing now in terms

3301.62.text: of the presidential review of those things

3307.56.text: But in my judgment it's very, very important

3311.33.text: that the president, whomever or she is has some independent

3318.53.text: or quasi-independent group of people working

3322.34.text: and advising the White House on the intel gathering machinery.

3327.71.text: >> As the follow up to that, if you were still Secretary of DHS,

3333.97.text: how would you balance the need for secrecy versus a need

3337.92.text: for disclosure of potentially illegal government surveillance

3342.46.text: and other individuals in the news?

3346.53.text: >> You know, these are, these are as you might imagine,

3349.71.text: there's no black or white answer on some of these.

3355.50.text: And you have to look at what was the surveillance?

3359.77.text: And then you have to look at what was obtained?

3361.66.text: You have to look at what was the danger that was sought to be

3366.35.text: or the risk that was sought to be mitigated?

3369.27.text: And those things are changing all the time.

3373.00.text: So and what should be disclosed or not, I do think,

3379.81.text: like I said before, the president needs greater capacity

3384.28.text: within the White House structure to have transparency and insight

3403.46.text: What you disclose in the popular press, I think by nature

3409.51.text: of what you're dealing with by and large will be very

3415.94.text: Because you're mitigating risk, you're protecting security,

3419.68.text: you're exchanging information that may have been gathered

3424.19.text: by another country that you don't, that, you may possess

3429.64.text: So there are a lot of things that go into it.

3432.64.text: Now in terms of Snowden, I'm on record.

3435.69.text: I would not give him clemency.

3438.07.text: I don't think he was entitled by himself

3440.56.text: to decide what information should be disclosed

3444.33.text: And there is a real whistleblower procedure

3450.07.text: It exists there for a reason.

3451.91.text: He should have used what he was allowed to do under the law.

3456.48.text: So I, I'm not a Snowden sympathizer.

3463.96.text: Sorry to those of you who are, but I think he broke the law.

3474.59.text: >> So now moving back to your current role, as a President

3477.92.text: of a large university system, what are your thoughts

3480.92.text: on the role of athletic teams especially football

3490.84.text: >> Well I'm, I'm, first of all, oh congratulations

3499.13.text: He had a very good record with the 49ers

3501.27.text: and I think he'll do a great job for you.

3503.96.text: And I'm, I'm, I think he'll probably help the Ann Arbor real

3511.45.text: He'll probably buy a pretty nice house.

3515.00.text: I, I think if you got a group of university presidents together,

3520.59.text: we would all just go what the heck?

3523.34.text: You know, there's just, there's an arms race going on out there.

3527.77.text: And have we, you know, what do we do about it?

3533.64.text: What can we do about it?

3536.31.text: And I think my first level

3540.50.text: of concern quite frankly is how are we treating the

3545.55.text: You know, one of the most embarrassing stores we had

3548.97.text: at UC last year was the graduation rate

3552.97.text: It was one of the lowest in the NCAA.

3558.46.text: And we put a lot in and we got a new coach

3561.51.text: and a new athletic director at Berkley.

3563.77.text: That problem is going to, is being addressed.

3566.40.text: And fix how we got there is another set of issues.

3570.57.text: And because I don't want that process repeated.

3573.51.text: So, how we treat those student athletes when we're,

3577.33.text: when they're practicing so many hours a week and doing this

3580.17.text: and that and traveling, etc. etc.

3581.74.text: And when I say the student athletes,

3583.46.text: I'm talking about football and basketball.

3586.58.text: The revenue producing teams which is I think

3594.33.text: We need to make sure that those young men graduate with,

3599.10.text: graduate with degrees they can use so that they can, you know,

3603.62.text: be like other students at the university.

3606.83.text: And I've had a terrific time playing

3609.19.text: on a great football team at the same time.

3612.25.text: So let's, let's, let's start with the academics

3619.25.text: That may mean looking at admissions of student athletes

3624.05.text: And are they really prepared to undertake the curriculum

3628.10.text: at a school like Michigan or CAL or UCLA.

3633.56.text: I'm sure you are as well.

3635.84.text: And one of the things that our regents will be voting

3639.04.text: on this coming week is the incorporation

3641.61.text: of academic performance criteria into the contracts

3646.33.text: of all athletic coaches and the athletic directors

3651.70.text: So there's an expressed recognition upfront

3655.41.text: that these are and let's not minimize, these are schools.

3665.99.text: These are students who have a particular talent.

3670.78.text: We need to foster both of those things

3673.16.text: and put it in the contracts.

3675.23.text: Our regents will vote on that next week.

3677.39.text: >> As you were doing your introduction,

3680.77.text: you passed a policy or where 5 million dollars were given

3685.98.text: What do you see as part of their aid to attend UC?

3689.21.text: What do you see as the follow up steps to these kinds

3691.83.text: of policies, to support undocumented students?

3694.23.text: >> Yeah, a lot of it has, has to do with providing places

3699.51.text: on campus where not only can they be,

3704.34.text: I mean, if you're undocumented student you typically are low

3708.66.text: income and first generation meaning that no, no,

3712.85.text: neither parent has ever gone to college.

3714.60.text: So, you know, a place where you can go with students,

3724.98.text: Maybe help with your immigration situation.

3728.44.text: So each campus has its own plan for how

3732.26.text: to spend the grant it got under the,

3739.31.text: And we hope in the spring

3741.50.text: to host the first national conference

3743.78.text: on undocumented students because at UC we probably have clearly

3750.26.text: more than 2,000 undergraduates who are undocumented.

3759.57.text: >> How can we as a nation promote more women

3765.15.text: >> I want more women to run, run.

3770.74.text: I think that, that's what I said in my remarks.

3774.88.text: Look, you can't win if you don't run.

3776.91.text: It's kind of a thing, you know, you got to,

3779.81.text: you got to be in the race.

3783.72.text: I think making sure women feel prepared.

3788.48.text: Women always want to be, feel, be more prepared than guys do.

3792.63.text: I'm just making broad generalizations now so,

3795.89.text: you know, give me a break.

3798.55.text: But, you know, women tend to, you know,

3800.65.text: want to make sure they've taken the last possible class

3803.76.text: and they've done the last possible thing

3807.01.text: As just saying look, whose in that job right now?

3810.18.text: Can I do a better job?

3812.42.text: Yeah, I can do a better job.

3816.39.text: And then really think through seriously what it takes

3822.41.text: to run a political campaign and get some help with that.

3836.30.text: in any possible way you can.

3837.92.text: And when you're starting on a new job, you know,

3841.69.text: be the one who volunteers to take on a particular project,

3844.83.text: to form a team, to look at this or that.

3849.21.text: Those experiences are invaluable in terms

3851.92.text: of developing your own style, how you lead an organization.

3859.17.text: And then listen and speak with women who have been

3866.65.text: And learn from them because there are lessons

3871.05.text: All of us have made mistakes.

3874.17.text: And we're still standing and we're still doing things.

3876.86.text: So how do you deal with that?

3881.59.text: But I think, you know, kind of having, having some hutzpah

3887.52.text: and raising your hand and taking

3889.12.text: that leadership initiative will pay off in innumerable ways.

3893.83.text: >> In your fellow remarks at DHS you warned about cyber-attacks.

3900.60.text: Is government and private sector falling behind the hackers?

3903.50.text: And as a leader of the UC system are large public institutions

3907.45.text: like the UC, should cyber security be a concern for them?

3912.35.text: >> Yeah, I think it should be.

3913.37.text: I think it should be a concern of the United States.

3916.90.text: I actually engaged several talks as the Secretary about the need

3924.53.text: The need for a legislation that would clarify the roles

3928.51.text: within the federal government, you know,

3937.75.text: What was DHS by way of example?

3940.88.text: I thought that the owners and operators

3944.77.text: of critical infrastructure, our power grids, our water supply,

3950.27.text: key financial institutions needed to be

3953.94.text: in the cyber discussion in the cyber world.

3956.21.text: And have incentives and consequences on cyber security

3960.55.text: to protect consumers, to protect the community.

3967.12.text: And universities need to do a better job.

3970.99.text: You know, we posses all kinds of stuff.

3973.25.text: You know, student records, you know,

3975.28.text: your own personal records, we got that.

3980.68.text: All this sort of stuff that could be attacked and misused.

3985.46.text: And so tightening up our own systems,

3988.25.text: doing as much as we can.

3989.60.text: And then we should be educating the next, people right now

3995.18.text: who are cyber security professionals for good.

3998.68.text: I call it hackers for good, right.

4000.72.text: Not every hacker, most of them don't, are not criminal.

4004.64.text: But we need to have a greater number of people involved

4008.86.text: in cyber security who can then help us make sure we are

4014.49.text: as secure as we can be in the cyber world which is

4018.87.text: of course a very vulnerable one.

4021.62.text: So yeah, a lot of work to be done in that arena.

4024.27.text: >> Is supporting the arts good public policy

4029.62.text: for supportive creative innovation in society?

4034.54.text: I'm a huge art supporter by the way.

4036.51.text: And I think we ought to do more in the arts.

4039.25.text: So, I actually thought of being a music major in college.

4043.39.text: So that's, you know, I love arts on all forms

4047.05.text: and I think they are underappreciated.

4051.85.text: And I think no matter what field you're in you ought

4054.28.text: to have some, something in the arts that you really like

4058.24.text: and enjoy and we need to them accessible and affordable.

4061.87.text: So if that's the question from somebody in here who's

4064.86.text: in that class on public policy in the arts,

4067.28.text: that's in the whatever, go for it.

4071.64.text: >> On college campuses non-black students, faculty

4079.04.text: from the [inaudible] danger of being black

4080.89.text: in the U.S. What's universities role

4082.97.text: to make its student body is aware of the realities

4085.36.text: of racism towards blacks in the U.S.?

4090.19.text: >> That's kind of, I don't quite know

4093.85.text: that I appreciate what the question is getting at.

4097.06.text: But I do think as an, excuse me, as an educational institution

4102.46.text: if we're really looking at some of the fundamental things

4106.90.text: that underlie our society we have to acknowledge

4110.44.text: that we have not solved the issue of race

4122.70.text: And this seems to, you know, it seems to be kind of quiet

4125.84.text: for a while and then we'll have a Ferguson or an episode

4129.24.text: that raises its appearance in the public perception.

4134.82.text: I think, you know, it is time for the United States

4140.14.text: to acknowledge this is continued problem for all of us

4152.09.text: that communities are not relating better?

4159.61.text: They are the same in law but not the same in reality.

4164.36.text: I mean, there is just so much work that needs to be done.

4170.94.text: about are just the numbers African American who attend UC.

4178.98.text: of student body hasn't really moved in 20 years.

4184.72.text: And we're banned from using Affirmative Action.

4188.97.text: And how do you try to move that needle?

4191.95.text: And how to encourage more African Americans to come

4196.55.text: when it's kind of a chicken and the egg issue when there's

4199.81.text: so few, they feel like they may be uncomfortable on campus.

4206.83.text: These are things we're struggling with.

4208.83.text: I think UM might be struggling with them as well.

4211.71.text: And I think we start off first with really looking

4215.59.text: at the pipeline of students coming in and the pipeline

4221.60.text: So one thing we have then I put some extra money

4227.31.text: in last year is the President's Post Doc Fellowship Program

4234.48.text: from historically black colleges and universities.

4239.68.text: And those post docs more and more are coming

4243.38.text: into tenure track positions in the university,

4248.24.text: And they're in all academic disciplines.

4250.87.text: So the arts, humanities, social sciences, the STEM fields.

4259.53.text: that help diversify the faculty also have the benefit

4264.02.text: of helping underrepresented minority students feel

4268.15.text: like they belong on campus too.

4269.98.text: This campus is for them too.

4272.67.text: And go ahead and matriculate here.

4279.03.text: >> So in talking also about core values and opportunities

4283.30.text: of being American, one audience member said that that,

4287.24.text: I fear for our country and that I believe we no longer value

4295.11.text: How do you think we can reinstall this

4298.91.text: >> You know, I think they're, no I disagree, I disagree.

4303.09.text: I just think we don't talk about it that way.

4305.67.text: And I think, you know, as I said in my prepared remarks,

4311.05.text: They're not looking for the common good

4318.90.text: I think people like yourselves and myself,

4322.25.text: we ought to talk about it more.

4324.08.text: And we ought to be searching for common ground more.

4328.10.text: We don't have a good illustration

4333.07.text: I mean, every candidate for political office

4336.44.text: in the federal level ought to be challenged

4338.69.text: in a public debate specifically to say how do you intend to work

4343.84.text: within your caucus and how do you intend to work

4346.71.text: across the aisle to find common, the common good?

4355.21.text: I don't think many of our candidates have

4360.27.text: But I think it's a worthy,

4363.20.text: it's a worthy question that should be asked.

4366.00.text: And it should continue to be asked.

4370.67.text: And because, you know, it is very easy in this day and age

4376.12.text: to say we don't have common ground

4378.58.text: or we don't have a common vision of the common good.

4382.76.text: This remains the country in the world

4386.70.text: where most people want to come.

4390.20.text: You know, why do we have so much immigration,

4393.11.text: legal and illegal to the United States?

4395.26.text: Because it's still the best place with the most opportunity

4399.52.text: for your children, for yourself and for your children.

4406.78.text: That feeling of freedom and opportunity, you are not judged

4411.65.text: by your parents, you are judged ultimately by you, yourself.

4416.29.text: So let's work to keep that in the public eye

4420.23.text: and challenge people when they're campaigning,

4426.05.text: Not when they're in but when they're campaigning exactly how

4436.87.text: >> So this is the last question for today.

4440.71.text: Is it more challenging to be a [inaudible] secretary

4452.54.text: And a lot of you at the, are here at the public,

4457.17.text: the Ford School Public Policy or looking at public policy.

4470.13.text: There's lots of kind of institutional politics,

4474.10.text: kind of the interior politics as well as metapolitics.

4477.02.text: You're never going to run a large complex institution

4484.74.text: You know, as pleasant as you intend to be and as perfect

4488.89.text: as you are in all ways and it's not going to happen.

4491.46.text: And so you have to give up that expectation.

4494.15.text: And the challenges in each job are different.

4500.09.text: When you're the governor, you are the leader of the state.

4502.78.text: You're the president of the state in some ways.

4504.64.text: And everybody knows who you are.

4506.68.text: You're in the grocery store and people will come up to you

4508.81.text: and talk and you want them to do that.

4513.50.text: And you're working on great issues like education debt,

4517.01.text: hopefully will not be totally undone by your successor.

4522.21.text: Secretary of Homeland Security, there are many

4530.03.text: who think that's the toughest job in Washington DC

4532.83.text: because it's a new agency, it's spread all over the district

4541.44.text: It was less than 10 years old when I took

4546.51.text: So creating kind of an institutional presence

4553.21.text: And you're doing it at the same time as you're dealing

4555.77.text: with every conceivable kind of problem

4558.27.text: and disaster you can possibly imagine.

4561.64.text: From the Jihadist issues we were discussing earlier to cyber,

4567.54.text: immigration is very complex and frustrating issue,

4571.84.text: at least in the congress, to natural disasters.

4577.23.text: So FEMA is part of the department.

4580.39.text: There were some 365 federally declared major disasters during

4589.15.text: So you're always on call for a hurricane, a tornado,

4594.41.text: You know, everything from Hurricane Sandy

4598.44.text: to coordinating the federal response to the BP oil spill.

4603.90.text: So that is to say that that job requires someone

4610.68.text: who can be very flexible, be very good at coordinating a lot

4622.62.text: and can handle a lot of different types of crises

4627.87.text: that all happen at the same time.

4631.37.text: It is the 24/7 job in Washington.

4637.85.text: I really liked that job but physically it was a very,

4644.25.text: University President, what a great job.

4647.53.text: I mean, it's tough and I've got this budget issue.

4651.83.text: And the governor and I will work very hard to see

4656.62.text: if we can do something that's positive.

4659.16.text: I'm going to work with the legislature in California

4663.20.text: Because the University of California is one

4667.04.text: of secret sauce that's made California thrive.

4670.17.text: And it would be wrong to let it, to let it go backwards and not

4675.71.text: to support it and move it forwards.

4678.72.text: So, so you've got those, you've got the different campuses.

4683.29.text: You have some really tough issues.

4686.44.text: Like what is the degree of free speech on a college campus?

4694.45.text: I tend to take a very expansive view of free speech.

4697.73.text: But there's some risk involved with that in this day and age.

4704.05.text: We had a tragic mass shooting at Santa Barbara,

4710.45.text: So being the person to help lead again a very large [inaudible]

4719.17.text: But the pleasure of it and this is what I want to say

4724.99.text: And you all have been a great audience.

4727.70.text: You know, you talk about these jobs

4729.07.text: and the tendency to say it's so hard.

4731.91.text: You know, I think President Bush one time said oh this president,

4739.76.text: But it's hard because you have a lot of, you have a lot

4743.18.text: to do and a lot you can do.

4745.87.text: And part of what you're getting your education for is

4748.53.text: to start preparing yourself to take that on.

4752.74.text: And one of the ways that we need you to do that is being willing

4756.51.text: to run for office yourself ultimately.

4759.59.text: You may not do that your whole career.

4761.65.text: I haven't done it my whole career.

4763.87.text: But some of it in that arena is so very, very important.

4769.01.text: And when you think about the things you get to do

4773.87.text: and the lives you get to touch and what you can kind of count

4778.84.text: up on your ledger on the end of the day, the month, the year,

4782.49.text: the career, that's where public service really, really shines.

4790.02.text: And so yeah, they can be hard jobs and frustrating

4793.94.text: and difficult and you name it.

4796.77.text: And, you know, nobody likes reading a newspaper story that's

4802.30.text: But hey, get over it, move on.

4805.24.text: Because in the end you do that to give back

4810.59.text: and to give back a lot.

4812.71.text: And when you're talented and smart and you have the benefit

4816.26.text: of one of the best educations in the country,

4818.90.text: giving back means an awful lot.

4845.65.text: >> Well thank you very much President Napolitano

4849.34.text: for sharing your insights with us on such a wide range

4850.90.text: of topics and for your call to action

4855.44.text: It's nice to hear some very positive framing on some

4860.92.text: I'd like to thank again President Schlissel as well

4866.26.text: I'd also like to thank all of you for joining us here.

4869.43.text: And for all of your wide ranging questions.

4871.38.text: I know we didn't get to all of them but I invite you

4874.32.text: to continue the conversation with President Napolitano.

4877.33.text: We have a reception just outside in the lobby.

4881.88.text: And now just a final thank you to our special guest.
